It is used for PALS training of pilots, operators and maintenance personnel.
==History== The AN/SPN-46(V)2 was made to replace [[AN/SPN-42(T)1]], [[AN/SPN-42(T)3]], and [[AN/SPN-42(T)4]] radar systems.<ref>{{cite web|title=AN/SPN-46(V) PALS|url=http://electronicstechnician.tpub.com/14089/css/An-Spn-46-V-Pals-33.htm|website=electronicstechnician.tpub.com|accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref>
==Specifications== The system functions very similarly to the AN/SPN-46(V)1 system, which is carrier based, and not ground-based. The only major differences between them are that the (V)2 does not possess a MK 16 Mod 12 shipboard stabilization unit, and its antennas are {{convert|7|ft}} long, as opposed to the {{convert|4|ft}} long antennas of the V(1).<ref name="a">{{cite web|title=SIGNIFICANT INTERFACES|url=http://electronicstechnician.tpub.com/14089/css/Significant-Interfaces-34.htm|website=electronicstechnician.tpub.com|accessdate=16 March 2017}}</ref>

The '''Akron rubber strike of 1936''' was a strike by workers against [[Natural rubber|rubber]] factory owners in [[Akron, Ohio]].
During the late nineteenth and twentieth centuries, rubber factory workers, including those who worked for the three major rubber factories in Akron, OH, faced poor working conditions, low wages, and close to no benefits. The year 1936 was not only within this period in which rubber factory workers struggled with poor conditions and low wages, but also coincided with the period of the Great Depression in the [[United States]], as well as the passing of the [[National Labor Relations Act]]. The combination of all these conditions, as well as many other conditions, caused the founding of the United Rubber Workers in 1935, and the major picket strike of February and March 1936.
== Unions ==
=== United Rubber Council === In 1933, the same year the [[National Recovery Administration]] was established by President [[Franklin D. Roosevelt]], the [[American Federation of Labor]] (AFL) created a United Rubber Council (URC) to be a nationwide union for the industry. But workers at many individual factories had already organized federal local unions, and so recruitment was slow. So the AFL printed 50,000 leaflets and distributed them to the many rubber factories in Akron, Ohio, inviting workers to a recruiting meeting. About 5,000 workers showed up to hear the AFL's Paul Smith, and eventually about 50,000 workers joined the URC.<ref name=":2">{{Cite book|title=The Turbulent Years: A History of the American Worker, 1933-1941|last=Bernstein|first=Irving|publisher=Haymarket|year=2010|isbn=978-1-608460-64-9|location=Chicago, IL|pages=}}</ref> But during a rubber industry strike in 1934 and 1935, the URC's elected leadership reached terms with factory management that many striking workers felt far too unfavorable. The union's membership to plummeted below 5,000 members.<ref name=":0">{{Cite book|title=Strike!|last=Brecher|first=Jeremy|publisher=PM Press|year=2014|isbn=978-1-60486-428-1|location=Oakland, CA|pages=}}</ref>
=== United Rubber Workers === In its wake, the United Rubber Workers (URW) union was founded as the new industry-wide union. The AFL's William Green threatened to pull AFL funding from rubber-industry unions unless the URW elected as president the AFL's Coleman Claherty,<ref name=":1">{{Cite book|title=The CIO Challenge to the AFL: A History of the American Labor Movement, 1935-1941|last=Galenson|first=Walter|publisher=Harvard UP|year=1960|isbn=9780674131507|location=Cambridge, MA|pages=}}</ref> who had been directing AFL activity in Akron since 1933. The rubber workers rejected Claherty, a boilermaker by trade, and elected instead Sherman Dalrymple, president of the [[Goodrich Corporation|B.F. Goodrich]] factory's local union. So the AFL ceased funding the rubbr-industry union, after making one donation of $1,000 cash and passing along some URC assets: office furniture, equipment, and about $1,800 in a URC bank account.<ref name=":1" /> The URW eventually affiliated with the [[Congress of Industrial Organizations]] (CIO), and solidified itself as the prominent industry-wide union for rubber workers through the remainder of the Great Depression and until [[World War II]]. The URW is also one of the first few unions in the CIO that was founded without financial help from an outside organization.<ref>{{Cite book|title=Labor Conflict in the United States: An Encyclopedia|last=Filippelli|first=Ronald L.|publisher=|year=1990|isbn=0-8240-7968-X|location=|pages=}}</ref>
The passage of the 1935 [[National Labor Relations Act of 1935|National Labor Relations Act]], which guaranteed the right to organize and form unions, helped the CIO form many unions within different industries. But it did not require employers to recognize and cooperate with unions. [[Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company|Goodyear]]'s management, led by Paul Litchfield, did not wish to recognize the URW during negotiations.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Thirties in America|last=Lewis|first=Thomas Tandy|publisher=Salem Press|year=2011|isbn=978-1-58765-725-2|location=|pages=547}}</ref>
=== Goodyear Industrial Assembly === The Goodyear Industrial Assembly, founded in 1919, was a local union for employees of the Goodyear Tire plant. Many of the rubber factories had local unions in place to allow the workers and management of individual factories to bargain, and (during this time period) these local unions often existed at the same time as industry-wide unions. Because the Goodyear factory was more than twice the size of the next largest employer, the actions between the workers and management at the Goodyear factory had an effect on how the rest of the industry acted.
Goodyear's management and the leadership of the local union were able to cooperate and bargain until late 1935. During the later stages of 1935, Goodyear's management, led by Paul Litchfield,<ref>{{Cite book|title=International directory of company histories. Vol. 20|last=Pederson|first=Jay P.|last2=Grant|first2=Tina|publisher=St. James Press|year=1998|isbn=1-55862-361-2|location=Detroit, MI|pages=258–260}}</ref> introduced plans to reduce hourly wages, while at the same time moving from six hour shifts to eight hour shifts for its employees. The local union voiced its displeasure to management, but management was adamant on going through with the proposed changes, regardless of how the local union felt. Because the local union was now unable to negotiate with management, its perceived bargaining power decreased in the eyes of the workers, causing the union's support to decrease, and workers began to look elsewhere for union support (with many workers eventually joining the URW).
== Sit-down strikes == The [[Sitdown strike|sit-down strike]] was a type of strike that the rubber factory workers used very frequently both before and after the large picket strike of February–March 1936. The sit-down strike is when factory workers, who are currently working on the assembly line, sit down at their assembly line positions to stop production at their point in the production process. The stoppage of production in one department will cause the next department in the process to stop because that department will have no new products or batches to work with. Because one department decides to sit down, it causes the rest of an assembly line to cease production.
The workers in the rubber industry got the idea of using the sit-down strike from a strike that occurred at a baseball game that was played between union members from different factories.<ref name=":0" /> The players, who were union members, disliked an umpire who was not a union member, so the players decided that they would rather sit down on the field than play in a game that would be umpired by someone who was not a member of their union. The sit-down strikes in Akron, OH are considered to be some of the earliest origins of the sit-down strike, even earlier than the [[Flint sit-down strike]] of 1936-1937.
The sit-down strike was used frequently by the rubber workers because of a few reasons. The most important reason for the sit-down strike being used is that it does not allow the factory's management to hire [[scab workers]] to continue production, because the sitting workers are occupying the space necessary for the work to be done. Another major reason as to why the sit-down strike was frequently used by the rubber workers was due to management's inability to use force in order to get the striking workers out of the way. Factory management would rarely use force to drive out striking employees because of the fear of damaging expensive equipment used in the manufacturing process. These reasons also allowed the sit-down strike to be an effective tool for the workers.
== The picket strike of February–March 1936 == The large picket strike of February–March 1936 began in the Goodyear Tire factory, and then quickly spread to the rest of the rubber factories in Akron, OH.
Late during 1935, the management of the Goodyear plant, which was by far the largest employer of rubber workers in the industry, introduced a plan for the reduction of hourly wages for workers as well as a move from six hour shifts to eight hour shifts.<ref name=":2" /><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ohiohistorycentral.org/w/Akron_Rubber_Strike_of_1936?rec=461|title=Akron Rubber Strike of 1936|last=|first=|date=|website=Ohio History Central|publisher=Ohio History Connection|access-date=February 28, 2016}}</ref> The reason for management's plan was to save money on labor. The move to eight hour shifts from six hour shifts would cause significant layoffs of around 1,200 workers, because with six hour shifts, four shifts of workers would be employed compared to three shifts of workers being employed under eight hour shifts. Eventually, Goodyear's management decided to go back to six hour shifts because of the displeasure voiced by workers.
During the early stages of 1936, shortly after Goodyear's management decided to go back to the six hour shifts for its employees, Goodyear was forced to layoff around 700 workers due to decreases in tire sales.<ref name=":0" /> This round of layoffs ended up being the final event between management and workers that caused the workers to start the picket strike on February 14, 1936.
Throughout the strike, there were as many as 10,000 workers, which included people from all trades in the city of Akron, that picketed around the many gates to the Goodyear factory.<ref name=":0" /> The leaders of the strike were able to maintain strong morale amongst the striking workers during the strike largely due to the playing of music.<ref name=":2" /> There are a couple of known attempts to break the picket strike by using force, the first of which was by the police. The sheriff's force consisted of around 150 deputies as the force approached the striking workers. At the last possible second, the sheriff's force deciding against attempting to break up the striking workers due to number of people that they would be confronting.<ref name=":0" />
The second known attempt to break the strike by using force would have been by a Law and Order League. This group was financially funded by Goodyear and was managed by a former mayor of Akron. The group consisted of approximately 5,200 members that were fully prepared to attack the striking workers if told to do so. As a way of avoiding a violent confrontation, the Summit County Central Labor Council was able to convince the Law and Order League to not attack the striking workers.
During the time of the picket strike, Goodyear's management and the URW were busy negotiating terms that would allow for the workers to go back to the factories and continue production. Goodyear's management refused to formally sign any agreements between the two sides, causing the negotiation process to potentially take longer than it should have. By the end of the negotiating process, Goodyear had capitulated on many of the major demands by the workers. These demands included layoffs by seniority, six hour work shifts, and regular meetings between management and union representatives. The workers came away from the strike largely victorious, and their excitement was shown by a march of 5,000 delighted workers throughout the streets of Akron following the announcement that the strike was over.
Even though the strike had halted production for about a month, Goodyear had three months of inventory built up prior to the beginning of the strike, so the company did not lose any potential sales revenue by not being able to meet demand. Also, despite the length and size of the strike, no lives were lost and injuries were practically nonexistent.<ref name=":2" />
{{refimprove|date=March 2009}}

{{for|the Australian pioneer|Alexander Adie (Australian pioneer)}} {{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} '''Alexander James Adie''' [[FRSE]] [[Member of the Wernerian Society|MWS]] (1775, [[Edinburgh]] – 4 December 1858, Edinburgh) was a Scottish maker of medical instruments, optician and meteorologist. He was the inventor of the [[sympiesometer]], patented in 1818.<ref name=RSE>{{cite report|url=http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/fellowship/all_fellows.pdf |title=Former Fellows of the Royal Society of Edinburgh, 1783–2002, Biographical Index |publisher=Royal Society of Edinburgh |date=July 2006 |section=Part 1, A-J |page=6 |isbn=0 902 198 84 X |location=22-26 George Street, Edinburgh, EH2 2PQ, UK |accessdate=2 July 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080828135318/http://www.royalsoced.org.uk/fellowship/all_fellows.pdf |archivedate=28 August 2008 }}</ref>
==Life== [[File:10 Regent Terrace, Edinburgh 2015.JPG|thumb|10 Regent Terrace, Edinburgh]] [[File:The grave of Alexander James Adie, Greyfriars Kirkyard.jpg|thumb|The grave of Alexander James Adie, Greyfriars Kirkyard]] He was born the son of John Adie.
He was apprenticed in 1789 to his uncle John Miller. They later went into business together as Miller and Adie, Mathematical Instrument Makers, which continued until 1822.
His shop was at 58 [[Princes Street]].<ref>{{Cite web| url = http://digital.nls.uk/directories/browse/pageturner.cfm?id=83399607&mode=transcription| title= Post-Office Annual directory for Edinburgh and its environs 1832–33|page= 37 |accessdate=2 July 2015}}</ref>
Adie supplied lenses to [[Joseph Dalton Hooker|Joseph Hooker]], [[Charles Darwin]]<ref>''Darwin Correspondence'' Vol 3, p 358, Letter 1012</ref> and [[Sir David Brewster]] and was optician to William IV and to Queen Victoria.<ref name="Anne"/> He invented the sympiesometer or marine barometer and had a small observatory erected long before there was a public observatory in Edinburgh.<ref name="Anne"/> He was elected as Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]] on 25 January 1819, upon the proposal of Lord F Gray, [[Sir David Brewster]] and James Russell.
Adie lived at 10 [[Regent Terrace]], Edinburgh, from 1832 to 1838.<ref name="Anne">Mitchell, Anne (1993), ''The People of Calton Hill'', Mercat Press, James Thin, Edinburgh, {{ISBN|1-873644-18-3}}.</ref> He died at Caanan Lodge, in the [[Morningside, Edinburgh|Morningside]] district of Edinburgh (now demolished) in December 1858, and was interred in [[Greyfriars Kirkyard]]. The grave lies to the south-west of the church, just to the north-east of the [[William Adam (architect)|Adam]] mausoleum.
His daughter married [[Thomas Henderson (astronomer)|Thomas Henderson]] (1798–1844). Henderson is buried with Adie but is not listed on the memorial.
==Alexander James Adie (railway engineer)== [[File:The grave of Alexander James Adie, St Michaels Churchyard, Linlithgow.jpg|thumb|The grave of Alexander James Adie, St Michaels Churchyard, [[Linlithgow]]]] Adie's son was born on 16 December 1808 and also named Alexander James Adie after his father.<ref name = RSE/>
He studied at the [[Royal High School, Edinburgh|High School in Edinburgh]] and then [[Edinburgh University]] before training as a civil engineer under [[James Jardine]].
In 1836 he became Resident Engineer on the Bolton, Chorley and Preston Railway. In 1863 he became Manager of the Edinburgh and Glasgow Railway.
In February 1846 he followed in his father's footsteps and was elected a Fellow of the [[Royal Society of Edinburgh]].
He died at his house, Rockville near [[Linlithgow]], on 3 April 1879. He is buried on the south side of St Michael's Church in Linlithgow.

[[Distinguished Service Order|Companion of the Distinguished Order]] | relations = | laterwork = }} [[Major-general#Canada|Major General]] '''Bertram Meryl "Bert" Hoffmeister''' {{postnominals|country=CAN|OC|CB|CBE|DSO*|ED}} (15 May 1907 – 4 December 1999) was a [[Canadians|Canadian]] [[Canadian Army|Army]] officer, businessman, and conservationist. ==Biography== [[File:Hoffmeister e010786144-v8.jpg|thumb|left|Bert Hoffmeister]] Born in [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] to parents Louis and Flora, he was a sales manager with the Canadian White Pine Co. Ltd. in Vancouver. He enlisted with the [[Non-Permanent Active Militia]] (NPAM, the Canadian Army Reserve Force) in 1927. He was promoted [[Captain (Canadian army and air force)|captain]] in 1934. After he was promoted to major, in 1939, he was made officer commanding a company of the [[The Seaforth Highlanders of Canada|Seaforth Highlanders of Canada]] who went to England in 1939. He attended the Canadian Junior War Staff courses at the [[Royal Military College of Canada]] in [[Kingston, Ontario]]. In 1942, he was promoted to [[lieutenant colonel]]. In 1943, he was awarded the [[Distinguished Service Order]] while [[Allied invasion of Sicily|fighting in Sicily]].[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36232/supplements/4847] He received a bar to the DSO the following year[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36668/supplements/3924] In October 1943, promoted to [[brigadier general]], he was named commanding officer of the 2nd Canadian Infantry Brigade, who fought in the [[Italian Campaign (World War II)|Italian Campaign]]. In March 1944, he was promoted to major general and made general officer commanding the [[5th Canadian Armoured Division]]. After VE-Day, he was made general officer commanding the [[6th Canadian Infantry Division|6th Canadian Division]] (Canadian Army Pacific Force) which disbanded after the atomic bombings of Japan. Hoffmeister retired from active service in September 1945. That same year, he was made a Grand Officer in the [[Order of Orange Nassau]] with swords as well as a Companion of the [[Order of the Bath]] [http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/37161/supplements/3490] and a Commander of the [[Order of the British Empire]].[http://www.london-gazette.co.uk/issues/36785/supplements/5129] In 1947, he was made a Commander of the [[Legion of Merit]]. After the war, in 1949 he became president of [[MacMillan Bloedel Limited]] and was its chairman from 1956 to 1958. From 1958 to 1961, he was British Columbia's agent general in London. From 1961 to 1968, he was chairman of the Council of Forest Industries of British Columbia, an association for the British Columbia interior forest industry. From 1971 to 1991 he was the founding chairman of the Nature Trust of British Columbia, a non-profit land conservation organization. In 1982, he was made an Officer of the [[Order of Canada]], Canada's highest civilian honour. ==References== {{reflist}} *{{cite web|url=http://www.junobeach.org/e/3/can-pep-can-hoffmeister-e.htm|title=Major-General B.M. Hoffmeister|work=Juno Beach Centre|accessdate=August 10, 2005 }} *{{cite web|url=http://www.utpress.utoronto.ca/cgi-bin/cw2w3.cgi?p=hiruki&t=74246&d=2258|title=Canadian Who's Who 1997 entry|work=[[University of Toronto Press]]}}{{dead link|date=July 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *{{cite book|title=The Soldiers' General: Bert Hoffmeister at War|author=Douglas E. A '''BitLicense''' is the common term used for a [[business license]] of [[virtual currency]] activities, issued by the [[New York State Department of Financial Services]] (NYSDFS) under [[regulation]]s designed for companies.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.wsj.com/articles/ny-financial-regulator-lawsky-releases-final-bitlicense-rules-for-bitcoin-firms-1433345396 |title=NY Financial Regulator Lawsky Releases Final BitLicense Rules for Bitcoin Firms |author=Michael J. Casey |date=3 June 2015 |work=WSJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.ft.com/intl/fastft/333531/ny-regulator-issues-digital-currency-framework |title=New York lays out requirements for a 'BitLicense' |work=Fast FT}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.usatoday.com/story/tech/2015/06/03/bitcoin-bitlicense-lawsky-rules-final/28405317/ |title='Bitlicense' rules regulating bitcoin released |author=Kaja Whitehouse, USAToday |date=3 June 2015 |work=USA TODAY}}</ref> The regulations are limited to activities involving the state of New York or a New York resident. People residing in, located in, having a place of business in, or conducting business in the State of New York count as New York Residents under these regulations.<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=http://www.dfs.ny.gov/legal/regulations/adoptions/dfsp200t.pdf|title=Regulations of the Superintendent of Financial Services, part 200: virtual currencies|last=|first=|date=|website=Department of Financial Services|access-date=April 13, 2017}}</ref> The license was introduced and designed by [[Benjamin Lawsky| Benjamin Lawsky]], New York's first Superintendent of Financial Services, in July 2014.<ref>{{cite web |url= http://money.cnn.com/2014/07/18/technology/bitcoin-license |title='New York unveils Bitcoin license rules' |author=Jose Pagliery, CNN |date=18 July 2014 |work=CNN}}</ref>. Chartered entities do not require an explicit BitLicense, but may instead proceed with virtual currency activities via limited purpose trust charters approved by the NYDFS.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/legal/regulations/bitlicense_reg_framework_faq.htm|title=BitLicense Frequently Asked Questions|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
==Overview== The regulations define virtual currency business activity as any one of the following types of activities: * receiving virtual currency for Transmission or Transmitting virtual Currency, except where the transaction is undertaken for non-financial purposes and does not involve the transfer of more than a nominal amount of virtual currency; * storing, holding, or maintaining custody or control of virtual currency on behalf of others; * buying and selling virtual currency as a customer business; * performing Exchange Services as a customer business, or; * controlling, administering, or issuing a virtual currency.
The two following activities are excluded from the definition of virtual currency business activity: * development and dissemination of software in and of itself; * merchants and consumers that utilize virtual currency solely for the purchase or sale of goods or services or for investment purposes.<ref name=":1" />
==History== On July 17, 2014, the department released details on a proposed "BitLicense", which places regulations on any company or person that uses [[Cryptocurrency|cryptocurrencies]] residing in New York.<ref name=bitlicense>{{cite press release|author=New York State Department of Financial Services|url=http://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press2014/pr1407171.html|title=NYDFS Releases Proposed BitLicense Regulatory Framework for Virtual Currency Firms|date=July 17, 2014|accessdate=July 19, 2014|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140923054843/http://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press2014/pr1407171.html|archive-date=2014-09-23|dead-url=yes|df=}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|first=Marco|last=Santori|url=http://www.coindesk.com/new-yorks-proposed-regulations-mean-bitcoin-businesses/|title=What New York's Proposed Regulations Mean for Bitcoin Businesses|work=CoinDesk|date=July 18, 2014|accessdate=July 19, 2014}}</ref> The proposed regulations were officially published in the ''[[New York State Register]]'' on July 23, beginning a 45-day comment period.<ref>''[[New York State Register]]'', [http://docs.dos.ny.gov/info/register/2014/july23/pdf/rulemaking.pdf Vol. XXXVI, Issue 23 (July 23, 2014)], pp. 14-16. Rulemaking I.D. No. DFS-29-14-00015-P.</ref><ref name=bitlicense/> On February 25, 2015, a revised proposal notice was published, beginning another 30-day comment period.<ref>''[[New York State Register]]'', [https://govt.westlaw.com/nyreg/Document/I41a4b512b7e311e493b50000845b8d3e?viewType=FullText&originationContext=documenttoc&transitionType=CategoryPageItem&contextData=%28sc.Default%29 Vol. XXXVII, Issue 8 (February 25, 2015)], pp. 17-18. Rulemaking I.D. No. DFS-29-14-00015-RP.</ref>
It came into effect on August 8, 2015. At least ten<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roberts|first1=Daniel|title=Behind the "exodus" of bitcoin startups from New York|url=http://fortune.com/2015/08/14/bitcoin-startups-leave-new-york-bitlicense/|website=Fortune|accessdate=10 October 2016}}</ref> [[bitcoin]] companies announced they were stopping all business in [[New York (state)|New York State]] because of the new regulations.<ref name="bjny-2015">{{cite web |url= http://www.bizjournals.com/newyork/news/2015/08/12/the-great-bitcoin-exodus-has-totally-changed-new.html |title=The 'Great Bitcoin Exodus' has totally changed New York’s bitcoin ecosystem |work=New York Business Journal |date=August 12, 2015 |author= Michael del Castillo}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://fortune.com/2015/06/11/bitcoin-shapeshift-new-york-bitlicense/ |title= Bitcoin company ditches New York, blaming new regulations |work=Fortune |date=June 11, 2015}}</ref> The ''New York Business Journal'' called this the "Great Bitcoin Exodus".<ref name="bjny-2015" />
In September 2015, Boston-based [[Circle (company)|Circle]] was granted the first BitLicense, although in December 2016 the company had pivoted away from its bitcoin exchange to focus more on payments.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://blogs.wsj.com/moneybeat/2015/09/22/circle-gets-first-bitlicense-releases-circlepay-new-service/ |title=Circle Gets First ‘BitLicense,’ Releases CirclePay, New Service |author=Paul Vigna |date=Sep 22, 2015 |work=WSJ}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.reuters.com/article/2015/09/22/us-bitcoin-regulations-idUSKCN0RM1TP20150922 |title=NY regulator issues first license for bitcoin company |author=Karen Freifeld |date=September 22, 2015 |work=Reuters}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.betaboston.com/news/2015/09/22/circle-gets-first-bitcoin-license-from-new-york-regulators/ |title=Circle gets first bitcoin license from New York regulators |author=Curt Woodward |date=September 22, 2015 |work=betaboston.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url= http://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1509221.htm |title= Press Release - NYDFS Announces Approval of first BitLicense application from a virtual currency firm |author=NYDFS |date= September 22, 2015 |work=ny.gov}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.coindesk.com/bitcoin-exchange-coinbase-receives-bitlicense/|title=Bitcoin Exchange Coinbase Receives New York BitLicense - CoinDesk|date=2017-01-17|access-date=2017-02-02|language=en-US|newspaper=CoinDesk}}</ref>
Two virtual currency limited purpose trust company charters were approved by the NYDFS in 2015, the first in May 2015 to itBit, now Paxos Trust Company, and the second charter in October 2015 to Gemini.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1809101.htm|title=DFS CONTINUES TO FOSTER RESPONSIBLE GROWTH IN NEW YORK’S FINTECH INDUSTRY WITH NEW VIRTUAL CURRENCY PRODUCT APPROVALS|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>
In October 2015, an article 78 was filed in the Supreme Court of the State of New York challenging the authority of the [[New York State Department of Financial Services]] to define virtual currency.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.article78againstnydfs.com/index.html |title=Article 78 against NYDFS |access-date=2016-11-06 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20161107014434/http://www.article78againstnydfs.com/index.html |archive-date=2016-11-07 |dead-url=yes |df= }}</ref> Justice St George heard the case on October 10, 2017<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.article78againstnydfs.com/docs/Index-101880-15/18-Hearing/01-Transcript-version.pdf|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20171031154334/http://www.article78againstnydfs.com/docs/Index-101880-15/18-Hearing/01-Transcript-version.pdf|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2017-10-31|title=New York State Supreme Court Hearing Transcript}}</ref> and dismissed the case on December 27, 2017<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.coindesk.com/judge-dismisses-long-shot-bid-overturn-new-york-bitcoin-law/|title=Judge Dismisses Long-Shot Bid to Overturn New York Bitcoin Regulation.|date=3 January 2018|work=Coindesk}}</ref> The case is currently on appeal.<REF>{{cite web |url=https://bitsonline.com/theo-chinos-fight-overturn-controversial-bitlicense|title=Theo Chino’s Fight to Overturn the Controversial BitLicense.|date=14 May 2018|work=Bitsonline}}</ref>
In July 2016, San Francisco-based [[Ripple (company)|Ripple]] was awarded the second BitLicense.<ref name=":0" />
In January 2017, San Francisco-based [[Coinbase]], one of the most heavily funded startups in the Bitcoin industry, was awarded the third BitLicense.<ref name=":0" />
In November 2017, Tokyo based [[bitFlyer]] was awarded the fourth BitLicense<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1711281.htm|title=DFS GRANTS VIRTUAL CURRENCY LICENSE TO BITFLYER USA, INC.|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref> and [[Genesis Global Trading]] was awarded the fifth BitLicense in May 2018<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1805171.htm=DFS CONTINUES ACTIONS TO SUPPORT RESPONSIBLE INNOVATION IN NEW YORK’S FINTECH INDUSTRY|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.

BitPay was awarded the eighth BitLicense in July 2018<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1807161.htm|title=July 16, 2018: DFS GRANTS VIRTUAL CURRENCY LICENSE TO BITPAY, INC.|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.
In November 2018, Texas-based Coinsource, an operator of Bitcoin Teller Machines, was awarded the twelfth virtual currency license or charter<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.dfs.ny.gov/about/press/pr1811011.htm|title=November 1, 2018: DFS GRANTS VIRTUAL CURRENCY LICENSE TO COINSOURCE, INC.|website=www.dfs.ny.gov|language=en-US|access-date=2018-11-06}}</ref>.

{{distinguish|Royal Astronomical Society of Canada}} {{Infobox organization | name = Canadian Astronomical Society | former name = | bgcolor = <!-- header background color --> | fgcolor = <!-- header text color --> | image = | image_border = | size = <!-- default 200px --> | alt = <!-- alt text; see [[WP:ALT]] --> | caption = | map = <!-- optional --> | msize = <!-- map size, optional, default 250px --> | malt = <!-- map alt text --> | mcaption = <!-- optional --> | map2 = | abbreviation = CASCA | motto = | predecessor = | successor = | formation = 1971 | extinction = <!-- date of extinction, optional --> | type = [[Non-governmental organization|NGO]] | status = <!-- ad hoc, treaty, foundation, etc --> | purpose = The promotion and advancement of knowledge of the universe through research and education | headquarters = [[Victoria, British Columbia]] | location = | coords = <!-- Coordinates of location using a coordinates template --> | region_served = | membership = 503 <ref>{{cite web | title = Membership | url = http://casca.ca/?page_id=61 | publisher = Canadian Astronomical Society | accessdate = 8 December 2017 | date = 31 May 2017}}</ref> | language = [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] | general = <!-- Secretary General --> | leader_title = President | leader_name = [[Robert J Thacker]] | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | key_people = | main_organ = <!-- gral. assembly, board of directors, etc --> | parent_organization = <!-- if one --> | affiliations = <!-- if any --> | budget = | num_staff = | num_volunteers = | website = http://www.casca.ca | remarks = }} The '''Canadian Astronomical Society''' (CASCA; {{lang-fr|link=yes|'''La Société Canadienne d'Astronomie'''}}) is a [[Canada|Canadian]] society of professional [[astronomer]]s, founded in 1971 and incorporated in 1983. The society is devoted to the promotion and advancement of knowledge of the universe through research and education, and its membership is open to people with a professional involvement in astronomy and related sciences.
The main activities of the Society are its annual scientific meetings, the planning and realization of scientific projects, the support of the scientific activities of its members, and the dissemination of related information among members and other interested people.
== History == Before World War II, there were few professional astronomers in Canada. There were two government-run, national observatories, the [[Dominion Observatory]], which opened in 1905 in [[Ottawa]], [[Ontario]] and the [[Dominion Astrophysical Observatory]], which opened in 1918 in [[Saanich, British Columbia]]. In addition, the [[University of Toronto]]'s [[David Dunlap Observatory]], which opened in 1935 in [[Richmond Hill, Ontario]], housed the only significant university faculty and the only centre for graduate studies in astronomy in Canada.
During this period, the most prominent astronomical organization in Canada was the [[Royal Astronomical Society of Canada]], which counted both amateurs and professional astronomer as members. Canadians also held leadership positions and attended meetings of the [[American Astronomical Society]] (AAS). Beginning with Ottawa in 1911, several Canadian cities hosted AAS meetings. Canada was also an early member of the [[International Astronomical Union]], with activities coordinated through the Dominion Observatory.
In the 1960s, University programmes in science expanded rapidly and astronomy groups and departments appeared across Canada. This influx of astronomers, along with the closure of the Dominion Observatory in 1970, created demand for a professional society of Canadian astronomers.
CASCA was founded in May 1971 by a committee of the Canadian government's [[National Research Council (Canada)|National Research Council]] and [[Helen Sawyer Hogg]] was elected as the first president. CASCA was incorporated in 1983 as a society of professional astronomers.<ref>{{cite web | title = History| url = http://casca.ca/?page_id=53 | publisher = Canadian Astronomical Society | accessdate = 8 December 2017 }}</ref>
== Publications == The quarterly newsletter of the Society, called ''Cassiopeia'' is published at [[equinox]]es and [[solstice]]s.

Definition: The '''Castner–Kellner process''' is a method of [[electrolysis]] on an [[aqueous]] [[alkali]] [[chloride]] solution (usually [[sodium chloride]] solution) to produce the corresponding alkali [[hydroxide]],<ref name="pauling">Pauling, Linus; ''General Chemistry'' 1970 ed. pp. 539–541 Dover publishing</ref> invented by American [[Hamilton Castner]] and [[Austrian people|Austrian]]<ref name="isbn0-419-24680-0">{{cite book |author1=Trinder, Barrie Stuart |author2=Stratton, Michael |title=Twentieth century industrial archaeology |publisher=E&FN Spon |location=London |year=2000 |pages=80–81 |isbn=0-419-24680-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref> [[Carl Kellner (mystic)|Karl Kellner]] in the 1890s.<ref name="saltman">[http://www.saltsense.co.uk/hist-chem12.htm Salt Manufacturers' Association: Salt and the Chemical Revolution] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070514034157/http://www.saltsense.co.uk/hist-chem12.htm |date=May 14, 2007 }}</ref>
==History== The first patent for electrolyzing [[brine]] was granted in England in 1851 to [[Charles Watt]]. His process was not an economically feasible method for producing sodium hydroxide though because it could not prevent the chlorine that formed in the brine solution from reacting with its other constituents. [[Hamilton Castner]] solved the mixing problem with the invention of the mercury cell and was granted a U.S. patent in 1892 ([http://www.google.com/patents/US528322]). Austrian chemist, [[Carl Kellner (mystic)|Karl Kellner]] arrived at a similar solution at about the same time. In order to avoid a legal battle they became partners in 1895, founding the Castner-Kellner Alkali Company, which built plants employing the process throughout Europe. The mercury cell process continues in use to this day.<ref name="chemchron">[http://pubs.acs.org/subscribe/journals/tcaw/11/i04/html/04chemistry.html Chemistry Chronicles]</ref> Current-day mercury cell plant operations are criticized for environmental release of mercury <ref name="oceana">[http://www.oceana.org/index.php?id=1707 Chlorine Plants: Major, Overlooked Source of Mercury Pollution, ''Oceana'']</ref> leading in some cases to severe [[mercury poisoning]] as occurred in [[Ontario Minamata disease]]. Due to these concerns, mercury cell plants are being phased out, and a sustained effort is being made to reduce mercury emissions from existing plants.<ref name="wcc">[http://www.chem.unep.ch/Mercury/partnerships/progress-reports/WCC%20Submission.pdf WCC Submission to United Nations Environment Program on Reduction of Mercury in the Chlor-alkali sector] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110525111624/http://www.chem.unep.ch/Mercury/partnerships/progress-reports/WCC%20Submission.pdf |date=2011-05-25 }}</ref>
==Process details== [[Image:HgNaOHElectrolysis.png|thumb|400px|right|Castner–Kellner apparatus]] The apparatus shown is divided into two types of cells separated by [[slate]] walls. The first type, shown on the right and left of the diagram, uses an electrolyte of sodium chloride solution, a [[graphite]] [[anode]] (A), and a [[mercury (element)|mercury]] [[cathode]] (M). The other type of cell, shown in the center of the diagram, uses an electrolyte of [[sodium hydroxide]] solution, a mercury anode (M), and an iron cathode (D). The mercury electrode is common between the two cells. This is achieved by having the walls separating the cells dip below the level of the electrolytes but still allow the mercury to flow beneath them.<ref name="newell">Newell, Lyman C.; ''Descriptive Chemistry'' p. 291; D. C. Heath and company, 1903</ref>
The reaction at anode (A) is:
:Cl<sup>−</sup> →1/2 Cl<sub>2</sub> + e<sup>−</sup>
The [[chlorine]] gas that results vents at the top of the outside cells where it is collected as a byproduct of the process. The reaction at the mercury cathode in the outer cells is
:Na<sup>+</sup> + e<sup>−</sup> → Na (amalgam)
The [[sodium]] metal formed by this reaction dissolves in the mercury to form an [[amalgam (chemistry)|amalgam]]. The mercury conducts the current from the outside cells to the center cell. In addition, a rocking mechanism (B shown by fulcrum on the left and rotating eccentric on the right) agitates the mercury to transport the dissolved sodium metal from the outside cells to the center cell.
The anode reaction in the center cell takes place at the interface between the mercury and the sodium hydroxide solution.
:2Na (amalgam) → 2Na<sup>+</sup> + 2e<sup>−</sup>
Finally at the iron cathode (D) of the center cell the reaction is
:2H<sub>2</sub>O + 2e<sup>−</sup> → 2OH<sup>−</sup> + H<sub>2</sub>
The net effect is that the concentration of sodium chloride in the outside cells decreases and the concentration of sodium hydroxide in the center cell increases. As the process continues some sodium hydroxide solution is withdrawn from center cell as output product and is replaced with water. Sodium chloride is added to the outside cells to replace what has been electrolyzed.

The '''Directorate of Matriculation Schools, Tamil Nadu''' is an accreditation and governing body for secondary schools in [[Tamil Nadu]], [[India]]. In a concept unique to Tamil Nadu (within India), until 1971 Universities also governed secondary schools, and such schools were accredited to the ''Matriculation'' system.<ref name="Education world">{{cite journal|date=2004|journal=Education world: the human development magazine|publisher=D. Thakore|volume=6|issue=1-6}}</ref> About 5% of schools in Tamil Nadu fall under this system.<ref>{{cite book|title=Medium of instruction policies: which agenda? whose agenda?|editor=James W. Tollefson and Amy Tsui|publisher=Lawrence Erlbaum|date=September 1, 2003|pages=187|isbn=0-8058-4278-0}}<!--|accessdate=2009-08-17--></ref>
Schools use [[English language|English]] as the language of instruction. They have a unique curriculum until class 10 and follow the [[Tamil Nadu Board of Secondary Education|Tamil Nadu State Board]] curriculum for classes 11 and 12.<ref>{{cite book|last=Soo|first=Neelam|title=Management of School Education|publisher=APH Publishing Corporation|date=December 1, 2003|pages=179|isbn=81-7648-500-4}}</ref> Schools are accredited on an annual basis.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.hindu.com/2004/05/26/stories/2004052600660300.htm|title=Permanent recognition sought for matriculation schools |date=May 26, 2004|publisher=[[The Hindu]]|accessdate=2009-08-17}}</ref>
For the academic year 2008-09, 2.31 million students were enrolled in the matriculation schools with a boy to girl ratio of 1:0.9. From 2001 to 2008, the pass percentage has been 90 and above excepting for 2002 when it dipped to 87.

In October 2010, after leaving Adobe, James started Shacho, Inc.<ref>{{cite news|author=Ferguson, Joey |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/700151469/Omniture-founder-Josh-James-launches-Domo-business-intelligence-with-43-million.html |title=Omniture founder Josh James launches Domo, Inc. business intelligence with $43 million |work=Deseret News |date= |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref> Two months later, as one of its first moves, Shacho purchased Lindon-based Corda Technologies<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.techrockies.com/shacho-gets---m-buys-corda/s-0035819.html|title=Shacho Gets $10M, Buys Corda - silicontap.com|website=www.techrockies.com|access-date=2018-08-17}}</ref> to jump start the data visualization component of the product. At the time, Corda had grown to about $10 million in annual revenue. James changed Shacho's name to Domo,<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/07/14/domo-idUSN1E76C0ZT20110714 |title=Omniture founder obtains $33 mln for start-up |work=Reuters |date= July 14, 2011|accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref> which means ''thanks'' in [[Japanese language|Japanese]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.dummies.com/languages/japanese/expressing-gratitude-and-regret-in-japanese/|title=Expressing Gratitude and Regret in Japanese - dummies|work=dummies|access-date=2018-08-17|language=en-US}}</ref>{{citation needed|date=December 2015}}
== Investors == As of December 2016 the company has raised a total of $589 million.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/domo#/entity|title=Domo Funding Rounds|last=|first=|date=|website=crunchbase.com|publisher=Crunchbase|access-date=2016-12-14}}</ref> Benchmark Capital, [[Andreessen Horowitz]], [[Ron Conway]] and [[David Lee (investor)|David Lee]] of SV Angel, [[Hummer Winblad]], salesforce.com’s [[Marc Benioff]], and [[Fraser Bullock]] of Sorenson Capital invested the first $43 million.<ref name="yahoo1"/><ref name="venturebeat1">{{cite news|url=https://venturebeat.com/2012/01/31/business-intelligence-startup-domo-pulls-in-another-20m/ |title=Business intelligence startup Domo pulls in another $20M |work=VentureBeat |date= |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://techcrunch.com/2011/07/13/series-a-whopper-benchmark-invests-33m-in-new-bi-company-domo/ |title=Series A Whopper: Benchmark Invests $33M in New BI Company Domo |website=TechCrunch |date=July 13, 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref> Later on in 2011, $20 million came from [[Silicon Valley]]-based [[Institutional Venture Partners]], which previously invested in Josh James’ previous start-up, Omniture.<ref name="yahoo1"/><ref name="venturebeat1"/> In 2013, the company announced a Series B investment of $60 million from [[GGV Capital|GGV]] Capital, Greylock, Bezos Expeditions, and Co-CEOs of Workday, Aneel Bhusri and Dave Duffield.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2013/03/11/exclusive-omniture-co-founders-business-intelligence-saas-company-domo-raises-60m-from-ggv-capital-jeff-bezos-greylock-and-others/|date=March 11, 2013|website=TechCrunch|title=Exclusive: Omniture co-founders, business intelligence, SAAS company domo raises $60m }}</ref> In February 2014, Domo announced Series C funding of an additional $125 million from TPG Growth, T. Rowe Price, Fidelity Investments, salesforce.com, Morgan Stanley Investment Management, [[Viking Global Investors]], and Dragoneer Investments Group. Existing investors GGV Capital, Greylock Partners, IVP, and Mercato Partners also participated.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/02/05/us-venture-investment-domo-idUSBREA141HH20140205 |title= Josh James's Domo, Inc raises $125 million from TPG, others |website=Reuters |date=February 5, 2014 |accessdate=2014-02-06}}</ref> There also was an investment in March 2014 with an undisclosed amount.<ref name=":0" /> In April 2015, Domo, Inc raised another $200 million in Series D financing with a $2 billion valuation. The round was led by [[BlackRock]]. Glynn Capital Management, [[Capital Group Companies|Capital Group]] and existing investor GGV also participated.<ref>{{cite web|website=Wall Street Journal Blogs|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2015/04/08/domo-valued-at-2-billion-in-latest-funding-prepares-for-ipo/|date=April 8, 2015|title=Domo valued at $2 billion in latest funding, prepares for IPO}}</ref> By that time the company passed the $1 billion valuation threshold and is one of the so-called [[Unicorn (finance)|unicorns]] in the industry. In March 2016 the company closed a Series D investment round of $131 million with its existing investors and new investors, including [[Credit Suisse]] and Capital Advisors.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2016-03-22/domo-raises-131-million-creates-fund-for-app-developers|title=Domo Raises $131 Million, Creates Fund for App Developers|last=Chapman|first=Lizette|date=2016-03-22|website=Bloomberg.com|publisher=Bloomberg|access-date=2016-12-14}}</ref> On April 27, 2017 Domo raised $200 million in Series D funding led by [[BlackRock|Blackrock]], with participation from [[Capital Group Companies|Capital Group]], Glynn Capital Management, and [[GGV Capital]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2017-04-27/domo-seeks-200-million-in-funding-as-ipo-plans-remain-on-hold|title=Domo Raises Funding From BlackRock With IPO Plans on Hold|date=2017-04-27|work=Bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-04-28}}</ref> Domo, Inc. was listed on the NASDAQ Global Exchange June 29, 2018 with an initial offering of 9,200,000 shares at $21.00 USD per share. <ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.nasdaq.com/markets/ipos/company/domo-inc-841801-87035|title=DOMO, INC. (DOMO) IPO|website=NASDAQ.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-06-29}}</ref>
==Overview==
Domo, Inc is a form of [[business intelligence]] (BI) that is a business management platform, delivered as a service, to CEOs and executives. The service is designed to provide direct, simplified, real time access to business data without any IT involvement.<ref name="enterpriseappstoday1">{{cite web|url=http://www.enterpriseappstoday.com/business-intelligence/domo-saas-business-intelligence.html |title=Omniture Co-Founder Launches New Business Intelligence Venture |website=Enterprise Apps Today |date=July 14, 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.domo.com./what-we-do |title=What We Do :: Overview |website=DOMO |date= |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref><ref name="venturebeat1"/><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/money/53659175-79/leaders-global-james-group.html.csp |title=Utah’s Josh James among 192 Young Global Leaders |work= The Salt Lake Tribune |date= |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Hardy |first=Quentin |url=http://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/10/24/big-data/ |title=The Big Business of 'Big Data'|work= The New York Times Blogs| date=October 24, 2011 |accessdate=2012-09-06}}</ref> It is a software-as-a-service ([[SaaS]]) venture.<ref name="yahoo1"/><ref name="enterpriseappstoday1"/> The company's board of directors includes [[Matt Cohler]] and [[Mark Gorenberg]].<ref name="enterpriseappstoday1"/>
==Customers== Domo's customers include: [[Air Canada]], [[American Kiosk Management]], [[eBay]], [[Lacy Auto Parts]], [[Fox Sports]], [[Goodwill Industries|Goodwill]], [[H & R Block]], [[Lendio]], [[National Geographic]],{{which|date=May 2016}} [[Nissan]], [[Ogio]], Randall-Reilly, [[SAB Miller]], [[Sage Group|Sage]], [[Toys R Us]], and [[Xerox]], among many others.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.domo.com/company/customers|website=domo.com|title=Customers}}</ref>

{{EngvarB|date=June 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox criminal |name = Du Jun
杜军 |image_name= |image_size= 220px |image_caption= |birth_date = |birth_place = |place_of_residence = |education = |employer = [[Morgan Stanley|Morgan Stanley Asia Limited]] |known_for = Committing Hong Kong's largest and most high-profile [[insider trading]] case |nationality = |spouse = |occupation = Former stock broker, financial adviser, and managing director at [[Morgan Stanley|Morgan Stanley Asia Limited]] |conviction_status = Jailed |children = |charge = Nine counts of [[Insider trading|insider dealing]], one count of counselling or procuring another person to deal in the shares of a listed company prior to the announcement of an acquisition deal |conviction_penalty = Seven years imprisonment and [[Hong Kong dollar|$]]23.3 million fine }} '''Du Jun''' ({{zh|s=杜军|t=杜軍|p=Dù Jūn}}) is a Chinese businessman and financier with origins in Beijing. He was known for his role as former managing director of the Wall Street investment bank [[Morgan Stanley]] in Hong Kong. He was sentenced for a maximum seven years in prison in September 2009 and fined [[Hong Kong dollar|$]]23.3 million (about US$3 million) for his part in Hong Kong's biggest [[insider trading]] case – an "unprecedented" scam a judge said undermined the integrity of the leading Asian financial centre.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/09/18/AR2009091800669.html|title=Ex-Morgan Stanley banker jailed for 7 years in HK|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|work=[[The Washington Post]]}} {{Dead link|date=September 2010|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8262627.stm|title=HK banker jailed for insider deal|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|publisher=[[BBC]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2009/09/18/2690666.htm?section=world|title=Hong Kong banker fined $3m for insider trading|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]}} He was convicted on nine counts on 10 September 2009 but pleaded "not guilty to all charges.{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/asia-pacific/8248274.stm|title=HK banker guilty of insider deal|date=10 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|publisher=[[BBC]]}} He was also convicted of involving his wife in the scam. == Career == Du offered advice to [[People's Republic of China|China]]'s CITIC Resources, part of the [[CITIC Group]], who wished to buy a Kazakh oil field. He purchased stock from the company in return for this, later selling it and obtaining a profit of $33.4 million. According to the [[Securities and Futures Commission]] (SFC), Du purchased CITIC shares at least nine times in the early part of 2007. Upon discovery, he fled to China. == Arrest and trial == Du was arrested upon his arrival from Beijing at the [[Hong Kong International Airport]] on 10 July 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfc.hk/sfcPressRelease/EN/sfcOpenDocServlet?docno=08PR107|title=Former investment banker arrested and charged with insider dealing|date=11 July 2008|accessdate=18 September 2009|publisher=[[Securities and Futures Commission]]}} He was taken to appear before Garry Tallentire, Principal Magistrate of the Eastern Magistracy, the following day, making his court debut in the process. He went on to appear in the city's [[District Court (Hong Kong)|District Court]] on 23 September 2008.{{cite web|url=http://www.sfc.hk/sfcPressRelease/EN/sfcOpenDocServlet?docno=08PR134|title=Du Jun's insider dealing case transferred to District Court|date=5 September 2008|accessdate=18 September 2009|publisher=[[Securities and Futures Commission]]}} The SFC froze $46.5 million throughout their investigation and police assistance was also provided. The trial took 38 days before drawing its conclusions. Judge Andrew Chan claimed Du was "driven by sheer greed".{{cite news|author=Graeme Wearden|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2009/sep/18/former-morgan-stanley-md-insider-trading|title=Ex-Morgan Stanley boss jailed for insider trading|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|work=[[The Guardian]] | location=London}} Taped conversations which Du had with other bankers showed him claiming to have "a lot of inside information".{{cite web|author=Michael Herman|url=http://timesonline.typepad.com/law/2009/09/former-morgan-stanley-md-convicted-of-insider-dealing-in-hong-kong.html|archive-url=https://archive.is/20110810191515/http://timesonline.typepad.com/law/2009/09/former-morgan-stanley-md-convicted-of-insider-dealing-in-hong-kong.html|dead-url=yes|archive-date=2011-08-10|title=Former Morgan Stanley MD convicted of insider dealing in Hong Kong|date=10 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|work=[[The Times]]}} == Conviction == As well as the prison sentence and fine, Du received a five-year ban from taking high-profile posts in any listed company or dealing in any further of the type of business which resulted in his conviction. He is also expected to pay $0.93 million costs incurred by the Securities and Futures Commission's investigation into his actions.{{cite web|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2009-09/18/content_12077529.htm|title=Ex-Morgan Stanley banker gets 7 years in jail for insider dealing|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]}} == Reaction == Then-CEO of the SFC [[Martin Wheatley]] said that "This sentence sends the strongest possible message that insider dealing is not tolerated in Hong Kong and those found guilty can expect lengthy terms of imprisonment".{{cite news|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE58H1PI20090918|title=Ex-M.Stanley HK banker gets 7 years for insider trading|date=18 September 2009|accessdate=18 September 2009|agency=[[Reuters]]}} == References == {{reflist|30em}} {{2008 economic crisis}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Du, Jun}} [[Category:2009 in economics]] [[Category:Hong Kong businesspeople]] [[Category:Hong Kong investors]] [[Category:Perjurers]] [[Category:White-collar criminals]] [[Category:Hong Kong criminals]] [[Category:Prisoners and detainees of Hong Kong]] [[Category:People convicted of insider trading]] [[Category:Year of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Living people]]

'''The Euro Alliance of Payment Schemes (EAPS)''' was an international alliance of [[Europe]]an bank and [[interbank network]]s that had aimed to creating a [[pan-Europe]]an [[debit card]] system in the [[Single Euro Payments Area]] to rival [[Visa Inc.|Visa]] and [[Mastercard]] using existing country specific systems. It was launched in 2007 with the support of the [[European Union]] but failed and was abandoned sometime after 2013.<ref name=abandon>{{cite web |url=https://www.emerchantbroker.com/blog/payments-competition-in-the-world-high-risk-payment-processing/ |title=Payments Competition In The World of High Risk Payment Processing |date=March 24, 2017 |publisher=EMB}}</ref>
==History== The [[Brussels]]-based consortium, formally announced in July 2007,<ref>[http://www.card-alliance.eu/Documents/November_2007_01.pdf Press release], card-alliance.eu. (November 2007) Retrieved 2008-08-04.</ref> included such members as Electronic Cash in [[Germany]], PagoBancomat/Bancomat in [[Italy]], [[Multibanco]] in [[Portugal]], EURO 6000 in [[Spain]], [[LINK (UK)|LINK]] in the [[United Kingdom]] and EUFISERV, an [[Automated teller machine|ATM]] system operated internationally by the [[European Savings Banks Group]].<ref>[http://www.atmmarketplace.com/article.php?id=8839&prc=4&page=34 SEPA for cards on way to reality in Europe]. (23 May 2007) atmarketplace.com. Retrieved 2008-08-04.</ref><ref>[http://www.eufiserv.com/site/about.asp About], EUFISERV official site]</ref> Though not allying itself with EAPS, the [[European Central Bank]] spoke in February 2007 in favor of the work being done by EAPS as "the first step towards a consolidation of card schemes, leading to a European card scheme".<ref>Tumpel-Gugerell, Gertrude, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB Colloquium. (February 13, 2007) [http://www.bancaditalia.it/sispaga_tesor/ssp/sepa/int_com/punto_vista/The%20European%20Central%20Bank%20s%20view%20on%20SEPA.pdf The European Central Bank's view on SEPA] bancaditalia.it Retrieved 2008-08-04.</ref> Prior to the implementation of the EAPS alliance, only [[MasterCard]]/[[Maestro (debit card)|Maestro]] and [[Visa Debit|Visa]]/[[V Pay]] debit cards could be used abroad in Europe.<ref>Kenny, Peter. (June 21, 2007)[http://www.thriftyscot.co.uk/062007/banks-announce-low-overseas-debit-withdrawal.html Banks announce low overseas debit withdrawal] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821124108/http://www.thriftyscot.co.uk/062007/banks-announce-low-overseas-debit-withdrawal.html |date=2008-08-21 }} thriftyscot.co.uk. Retrieved 2008-08-04.</ref> EAPS was first initiated particularly to challenge MasterCard's hold on international debit payments.<ref>Wissenbach, Ilona. (June 20, 2007) [https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSL2081352320070620 European banks agree corssborder Mastercard rival] [[Reuters]]. Retrieved 2008-08-04.</ref>
According to European Card Review in 2007, EAPS was expected to play a less pivotal role in spreading the [[Single Euro Payments Area]] initiative than larger schemes such as the "Falkensteiner Group" which they believed to include [[UniCredit]], [[Société Générale]], [[ING Group|ING]] and [[Deutsche Bank]], but was nevertheless capable of a "marginal" role.<ref>[http://www.europeancardreview.com/CardNotes/CardNotes_01.html Debit cards: pressure continues for third scheme in Europe] (2007) European Card Review. Retrieved 2008-08-04 {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080726191042/http://www.europeancardreview.com/CardNotes/CardNotes_01.html |date=July 26, 2008 }}</ref> The "Falkensteiner Runde" (''Falkensteiner Circle'') - according to the Lafferty Group to consist of [[ABN AMRO]], Allianz Dresdner, [[ING Bank]], [[Rabobank]], [[UniCredit]], [[Deutsche Bank]], [[Société Générale]] and [[Commerzbank]] - was discussing an alternative interbank network based on the German [[Girocard]] network joined by the French [[Carte Bancaire]] network.<ref name="paysys2008">[http://www.paysys.de/download/SepaJan08.pdf "PaySys SEPA Newsletter - Jan. 2008"]</ref> About the same time in early 2007 another initiative was formed in the "PayFair" company in Brussels to implement the European Payment Scheme.<ref name="paysys2008" /> This effort was building an infrastructure from scratch focussing at first to rebuild the [[Point of sale|POS]] (i.e. non-bank) infrastructure in Belgium and Netherlands as of 2008 and expanded to Germany during 2010 via "easycash" terminals.<ref name="paysys2008" /><ref name="db2009" /><ref>[http://www.payfair.eu/news/ PayFair news], "22 Sept 2009 - EasyCash, key PayFair partner in Germany" Bergisch Gladbach</ref> Founded in 2008, the "Monnet Project" was unveiled in Frankfurt in 2009 listing the same members as reported earlier on the Falkensteiner Circle.<ref name="db2009">[http://www.dbresearch.de/PROD/DBR_INTERNET_DE-PROD/PROD0000000000244256.pdf "SEPA: Changing times for payments", Deutsche Bank Research, July 27, 2009]</ref><ref name="monnet2010"/> Later reports cite these three elements - Monnet Project, PayFair scheme, EAPS council - as the driving forces behind SEPA-centric alternatives for debit card networks.<ref name="mccaughey2010">[http://www.card-alliance.eu/assets/Uploads/Download-News/2010-01-10-Extract-from-Lafferty-Cards-Insider.pdf "A grand scheme"], Interview with EAPS board chairman Ugo Bechis, by Ronan McCaughey, 1. January 2010</ref>
Meanwhile the EAPS announced the bilateral cooperation of ATM interbank networks, namely the German Girocard acceptance at Italian Bancomat ATMs,<ref name="bancomat">http://www.card-alliance.eu/assets/2009-08-27-Bancomat-and-girocard-connected.pdf</ref> Italian Bancomat card acceptance at German Girocard ATMs<ref name="bancomat"/> and German Girocard acceptance at UK LINK ATMs.<ref>http://www.card-alliance.eu/assets/Uploads/Download-News/2010-07-12-EAPS-LINK-ZKA-Cooperation.pdf</ref> Independently the European savings banks had created the pan-European [[Eufiserv|EUFISERV]] network to mutually accept debit cards at their ATMs - Eufiserv was a founder of the EAPS council.
On May 5, 2010 the Monnet Project held a meeting in Madrid to endorse a European Card Project. From the 30 banks that were attending it occurred that 12 banks from 8 countries volunteered to join a consortium phase to detail the technical requirements and to prepare treaties on the foundation of a new bankcard payment company.<ref name="info2010">[http://www.dbgcm.db.com/wms//customers/dbfk_SEPA/pdf/12_SEPA_What_s_New_German_v0.7.pdf "Infobrief SEPA – Euro-Zahlungsverkehr - Nr.12"], May 2010</ref> The ECB welcomed these steps pointing to the [[China UnionPay]] example that a new bankcard brand can quickly gain acceptance with China UnionPay being accepted in 29 European countries plus 60 more countries worldwide)<ref name="ecb2010">[http://www.ecb.eu/press/key/date/2010/html/sp100505.en.html "SEPA for cards: more than a symbol of SEPA’s success"], Speech by Gertrude Tumpel-Gugerell, Member of the Executive Board of the ECB, at the Monnet Symposium organised by The Monnet Project, Madrid, 5 May 2010</ref> It was predicted that by 2010 the results of the consortium phase would lead into a definite decision to build a new bankcard infrastructure, this was not to be the case.<ref name="monnet2010">[http://www.fbf.fr/web/internet/content_presse.nsf/%28WebPageList%29/55D8698EF2868B8CC125771B0054C9E1 "PROJET MONNET - Une vingtaine de banques européennes prévoient de créer un nouveau système de cartes bancaires en Europe"], press release, 6. May 2010</ref><ref name="info2010" />
The project failed and was abandoned at some time after this.<ref name=abandon></ref>
